signature.instructions:
text
You will be given a clinical bedside handover transcript with speaker tags like [OUTGOING_NURSE], [INCOMING_NURSE], [PATIENT]. Your job is to extract SBAR elements as EXACT verbatim text spans and output ONLY a Python/JSON-style list of dicts:

[{"label": "SITUATION|BACKGROUND|ASSESSMENT|RECOMMENDATION", "quote": "<verbatim span>"}]

This task is scored with IoU (span overlap), so BOTH label choice and boundary choice are critical.

====================
ABSOLUTE RULES
====================
1) Verbatim only
- Copy characters EXACTLY as they appear (including curly apostrophes, em-dashes, capitalization, punctuation).
- Do not paraphrase or “clean up” grammar.
- Do not add/remove words.
- Quotes must be contiguous substrings from one location in the transcript (never stitch non-adjacent text).

2) Output only the list
- No prose, no headings, no explanations—only the list of dicts.

====================
BOUNDARY STRATEGY (most important)
====================
Gold scoring often prefers ONE contiguous “block” when the transcript presents a run of related clauses/sentences under the same SBAR category.

A) Prefer contiguous blocks when they naturally belong together
- If several adjacent sentences form one coherent SBAR unit, extract them together as ONE quote.
  Examples seen in scoring:
  - Situation often includes 2 adjacent sentences (e.g., post-op status + returned from theatre).
  - Assessment often bundles multiple adjacent findings (pain + meds/analgesia + devices; imaging + O2 + breathing exercises; nausea/wound/mobility together).
  - Background often bundles comorbidities + allergies + smoking history together if consecutive.
  - Mobility blocks may include “With assistance. Physio reviewed… He’s slow but safe… Needs supervision…” as ONE assessment block if contiguous.

B) But keep it minimal within that block
- Do not include unrelated lead-in identifiers (bed number, age, doctor) unless they are part of the clinically scored unit.
- If the scorer tends to exclude trailing modifiers, trim to the shortest form that matches typical gold:
  - Example: “She’s ambulant, short distances only around the ward. Self-caring” (omit “with very minimal assistance” if it appears but is likely not part of the scored unit).
- Avoid adding final punctuation if gold omits it. If the transcript has a period but gold usually ends before it, prefer stopping before the period only if that exact substring appears contiguously. (You must still copy exactly what you select.)

C) Do not over-extract
- Extract only items likely to be scored as SBAR. Do NOT extract extra “nice-to-know” lines that often don’t score, such as:
  - “She’s much better.”
  - “Observations have been stable.” (unless vitals/obs stability is clearly a central assessment block)
  - Routine courtesy instructions (“use call bell”, “I’ll leave you in good hands”) unless the task is explicitly clinical monitoring/action for staff.
  - Documentation status (“All documentation is up to date…”) usually not scored.

D) Include clinically-relevant QUESTIONS when they are the SBAR unit
- Questions about symptoms can be gold ASSESSMENT spans (e.g., “Any headache, dizziness, or nausea today”).
- If a question is asked, extract the exact question text (without extra surrounding lines) as ASSESSMENT when it reflects a targeted clinical assessment prompt.

====================
SBAR LABELING (content-based)
====================
SITUATION = immediate reason/current context for admission/episode
- Admission reason/presenting problem, injury, or day/post-op/procedure status.
- Often a concise block like: “Day X post-op…” + immediately adjacent context like “returned from theatre yesterday afternoon.”
- Do not include demographics/bed/doctor unless they are inseparable from the situation unit (usually they are not).

BACKGROUND = prior history/context not part of the immediate current state
- Comorbidities (e.g., HTN, COPD), allergies (“No known allergies.”), smoking history, language, social supports IF bundled and adjacent.
- Prefer extracting a single contiguous background block when these are listed consecutively.

ASSESSMENT = current clinical status/findings/devices/functional state
- Symptoms (pain, nausea), vitals stability when part of a key block, imaging results, oxygen therapy, PCA/lines/drains status, wound status, mobility/diet tolerance, toileting assistance.
- If multiple adjacent assessment items are presented in sequence, extract them together as one assessment block (common in gold).

RECOMMENDATION = what to do/plan/monitor next (actionable)
- Monitoring plans, escalation instructions, discharge criteria statements, “keep an eye on…”, “let me know if…”.
- Prefer the exact plan sentence(s) as a block when contiguous.
- Often the “plan for today…” sentence is gold as one recommendation block; include the lead-in if present (e.g., “the Plan for today is to …”).

====================
PRACTICAL CHECKLIST BEFORE FINALIZING
====================
- Did you miss any symptom/vitals question that could be a gold ASSESSMENT?
- Can any of your multiple small fragments be combined into one contiguous gold-like block (same label) to improve IoU?
- Did you accidentally include extra non-scored lines (documentation status, reassurance, generic call-bell advice)?
- Are your quotes copied exactly (including apostrophes like “He’s”, em-dashes “—”, and spacing)?

Return only the list of {"label","quote"} objects.
